examples.text: They believed she was possessed by devils.
He behaved like someone possessed by devils.

definitions.definition: a person who behaves badly, especially a child
used to talk about somebody and to emphasize an opinion that you have of them

examples.text: I miss the old devil, now that he's gone.
She's off to Greece for a month—lucky devil!
James was a handsome devil and rich, too.
They were handsome young devils in their uniforms, weren't they?

definitions.definition: people say Be a devil! to encourage somebody to do something that they are not sure about doing

examples.text: Go on, be a devil, buy both of them.

definitions.definition: used to say that it is easier and wiser to stay in a bad situation that you know and can deal with rather than change to a new situation that may be much worse
in a difficult situation where there are two equally unpleasant or unacceptable choices

examples.text: These berries are the devil to pick because they're so small.

definitions.definition: bad people often seem to have good luck
people who do not have enough to do often start to do wrong

examples.text: She blamed the crimes on the local jobless teenagers. ‘The devil makes work for idle hands,’ she would say.

definitions.definition: a very difficult or unpleasant job or time

examples.text: I've had a devil of a job finding you.
There'll be hell to pay when he finds out.

definitions.definition: used, in an unfriendly way, to tell somebody to go away
to do anything, even something really bad or dishonest, in return for money, success or power
people say speak/talk of the devil when somebody they have been talking about appears unexpectedly

examples.text: Well, speak of the devil—here's Alice now!

definitions.definition: used in questions to show that you are annoyed or surprised

examples.text: What the devil do you think you're doing?

wordOrigin: Old English dēofol (related to Dutch duivel and German Teufel), via late Latin from Greek diabolos ‘accuser, slanderer’ (used in the Septuagint to translate Hebrew śāṭān ‘Satan’), from diaballein ‘to slander’, from dia ‘across’ + ballein ‘to throw’.
